headline.main: More Troops, More Accusations, More Economic Stimulus
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED -- AN OVERVIEW: NOV. 6, 2001

lead_paragraph: Naturally, the Bush administration has wanted international support for its war on terrorism, but only up to a point. British troops aside, the idea of foreign armies joining the actual fighting in Afghanistan has hardly thrilled the Pentagon, where the feeling is that more players mean more back-seat drivers. So Washington has for the most part ignored offers of help. Until now. BUILDING THE MILITARY STAKES -- With European countries practically banging on the door, the United States took steps, however reluctantly, to expand the coalition's armed might. In Europe, public support for the war has weakened, and government leaders there sense that with a piece of the military action, their peoples will have a greater stake in seeing this campaign through to the end. France, Italy and Germany all want to send troops -- a significant development in particular for the Germans, who have not deployed soldiers beyond Europe since World War II.
